NEW MEMBERS PICKED FOR
O. D. K.
An election of new members was
held at a meeting of the Omicron
Delta Kappa Honorary Fraternity
last Sunday morning. An unusually large number of men were elected from all branches of activities.
Announcement of these elections,
however, will not be made known
until the public initiation, which
will: be held at one of the Thursday
assemblies, when a prominent 0. D.
K. alumnus will speak.
At the same meeting, the committee on the maintenance of scho-astic standard offered a favorable
report. The committee was organized a few weeks ago to help those
students engaged in athletics to
keep up in their classes.
It was announced that two universities had been granted 0. D. K.
:harters. These are Bowdoin College and at the University of Tennessee.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 17, 1922.
HOMEWOODPLAvSHOP TO
TRY NOVEL EXPERIMENT
TONIGHT
A novel experiment in dramatics
has been arranged by the board of
directors of the Homewood Playshop of Johns Hopkins, as main
feature of the program of the organization's first "shop night" entertainment of the season, which
will be staged this evening in the

GRIDIRON GOSSIP
Dr. Van Orman should have followed the examples of the Yale
coaches last Saturday and sent his
regulars to watch next week's opponents, while the second team took
care of Drexel. The first string
men learned only one thing from
Saturday's game: that there are capable substitutes on the squad and
every man will have to hustle to
hold his position.

C. E. Hall.
Two performances, each by a
separate cast, will be given of a
new one-act play, "Jeanne La
Porte," by Miss Audrey W. Davis,
a student in drama at Hopkins. The
purbose of the experiment is to provide the best opportunity for both
actors and playwright. One cast is
composed of inexperienced players,
who will be afforded a chance to
try out before an audience, while
the second cast is composed of persons who have showed marked
ability in their work.. This produc-

has had a large sign prepared reading "Goal Line," and will suspend
the same between the crossbars tomorrow. As the Maryland eleven
has not made a touchdown on a
college team this year, their coach
is afraid that his pupils will not
know where the goal line is or what
it is for.

INTE RFRATE RNITY BOARD
CLEARS UP VAGUE POINTS
ON AGREEMENT
At the last meeting of the Interfraternity Board the approaching Rushing Season was thoroughly discussed and several
vague points were discussed and
made clear.
The important clauses of the argument with the interpretations
placed upon them by the board
were reviewed, and fraternities
were warned that the board stood
ready to prosecute all breaches of
the Rushing Agreement. The fraternities were urged to co-operate
in a strict observance of the spirit
of the agreement.
Some of the rulings passed recently by the board are as follows:
That the agreement shall apply
to all first year men in the University no matter what their class
standing may be.
That no fraternity man may entertain any first year man in his
home prior to December 12 and
no fraternity man may attend any
entertainment given by or at the
instigation of a first year man.
That under no circumstances
shall a fraternity man bid or signify his intention of bidding any
first year man prior to December 12.
Owing to the shortness of the
four-day period of open rushing,
Freshmen are to be permitted to
accompany fraternity men at entertaintnents providing the Freshman shall bear his full share of the
expenses, and that the agreement
is not otherwise broken.
Members of the board were
urged to seek the co-operation of
all first year men, and to emphasize to them the importance of a
thorough knowledge of the agreement.

BOTANY CLUB TAKES HIKE
The Botany Club, under the
supervision of Dr. Johnson, t;)ok
a trip to Glenburnie last Saturday
afternoon. Many different kinds
of rare plants were encountered.
These included a peculiar type of
moss, numerous pitcher plants, and
a species of holly which shed; its
leaves in the winter. The trip was
enjoyed by the members of the
club who attended, and more interesting trips are planned for the
near future.

don't get it; one modern thing looks as queer as the next to

is the one American magazine to intelligently explain the meaning and interpret the trend of the new movements in art and
literature. It is the only magazine which publishes side by side.
— the best work produced by Americans
— the best work produced abroad
— the best work in traditional styles
the best work in the modern manner
in fiction, poetry, essays, criticism, and reproductions of the

You know that i a few years certain of our contemporaries,
whose work is anathema to the present generation, will stand
out like giants. They will be hailed as great artists and geniuses
by those who now lack the critical discernment to understand
what they are trying to do. The genius of Swift, Milton, Blake,
Moliere, Ibsen, Shelley, Poe, Thoreau, Melville, and Whitman,
to mention only a few, went unrecognized, except by the discriminating minority, in their own generation. Don't wait for
the next generation to see your contemporaries in perspective,
but enjoy their work now in The Dial, and accord them your
appreciation while they are yet alive.
In addition to the best work by the new generation, The Dial
presents the finest work by established writers: Joseph Conrad,
E. A. Robinson, George Moore, Thomas Hardy, and Anatole
France, appearing side by side with Sherwood Anderson, E. E.
Cummings, Waldo Frank, Van Wyck Brooks, T. S. Eliot, D.
H. Lawrence, and Ezra Pound. THE DIAL thus offers you the
unusual pleasure of comparing and criticizing.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 17, 1922.

4
INTE RFRATE RNITY BOARD
CLEARS UP VAGUE POINTS
ON AGREEMENT
At the last meeting of the Interfraternity Board the approaching Rushing Season was thoroughly discussed and several
vague points were discussed and
made clear.
The important clauses of the argument with the interpretations
placed upon them by the board
were reviewed, and fraternities
were warned that the board stood
ready to prosecute all breaches of
the Rushing Agreement. The fraternities were urged to co-operate
in a strict observance of the spirit
of the agreement.
Some of the rulings passed recently by the board are as follows:
That the agreement shall apply
to all first year men in the University no matter what their class
standing may be.
That no fraternity man may entertain any first year man in his
home prior to December 12 and
no fraternity man may attend any
entertainment given by or at the
instigation of a first year man.
That under no circumstances
shall a fraternity man bid or signify his intention of bidding any
first year man prior to December 12.
Owing to the shortness of the
four-day period of open rushing,
Freshmen are to be permitted to
accompany fraternity men at entertaintnents providing the Freshman shall bear his full share of the
expenses, and that the agreement
is not otherwise broken.
Members of the board were
urged to seek the co-operation of
all first year men, and to emphasize to them the importance of a
thorough knowledge of the agreement.

BOTANY CLUB TAKES HIKE
The Botany Club, under the
supervision of Dr. Johnson, t;)ok
a trip to Glenburnie last Saturday
afternoon. Many different kinds
of rare plants were encountered.
These included a peculiar type of
moss, numerous pitcher plants, and
a species of holly which shed; its
leaves in the winter. The trip was
enjoyed by the members of the
club who attended, and more interesting trips are planned for the
near future.

You know that i a few years certain of our contemporaries,
whose work is anathema to the present generation, will stand
